## Introduction

-   Presynaptic neuronal protein alpha-Synuclein overproduction and misfolding leads to aggregation between nerve cells.

-   This inhibits the transmission excessively, causing signals in the brain to become disrupted like in PD.

-   Clinical trials are trying to find a correlation between -Synuclein aggregates and PD-diagnosis by SAA (α-synuclein seed amplification assays) and cerebrospinal fluid.

<br>

**Technical focus:**

::: pf-box
Can α-synuclein seed amplification assays (SAA) reliably detect Parkinson’s disease? We compare fluorescence data from two PPMI projects to assess diagnostic potential.
:::

## Materials and Methods

**Materials:**

-   PPMI (Parkinson's Progression Markers Initiative) database

-   SAA (α-synuclein seed amplification assays) and cerebrospinal fluid.

-   The assay amplifies the protein and monitors the aggregation by measuring fluorescence intensity.

-   Aggregates of the protein form a beta-sheet structure that binds to a dye, and an observed increase in fluorescence marks formation of alpha-Synuclein-aggregates. A higher fluorescence will indicate more aggregates and at a certain threshold also possible PD.

<br>
